EXHIBIT C TO COMMON FACILITIES AGREEMENT OPERATOR DUTIES C1. Services. From and after the Effective Date, the Operator shall provide or cause to be provided the following services and take the other actions required pursuant to Section 4.2 of this Agreement (collectively, the Services ): (a) Operation and Maintenance. Managing, supervising, operating, repairing and maintaining the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area in accordance with the standards set forth in Section 4.2, including, without limitation, taking the following actions: (i) to pay and collect amounts due in connection with the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area, and to maintain one or more bank accounts wherein funds received by the Operator in connection with its duties hereunder shall be maintained; (ii) to expend monies necessary for the management, operation, maintenance and repair of the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area; (iii) to take the actions set forth in Section C2 below in the event of an emergency; and (iv) to oversee all investigations, studies, clean up, corrective action or response or remedial action required by any Governmental Authority authorized to regulate environmental or other matters or by any consent decree or court or administrative order now or hereafter applicable to the use, operation or ownership of the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area. (b) Procurement/Disposition of Equipment and Tools. Purchasing, renting or otherwise acquiring such equipment, machinery and tools necessary for the repair, management, operation and maintenance of the Common Interconnection Facilities. (c) Consultation with Parties. Consulting and cooperating with the Parties and other personnel responsible for operating and maintaining the Parties respective Projects in relation to the provision of the Services. (d) Reporting; Notices; Records. (i) Attending such regular meetings as any Party may reasonably request; provided, however, that the Operator receives at least five (5) business days notice of such meetings; (ii) Promptly after receiving the same, providing to the Parties written notice of any communications, orders or requirements of any other Party or any third party (including any Governmental Authority, interconnecting utility or transmission owner or operator) regarding the Common Interconnection Facilities or the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area; (iii) Cooperating fully and providing such records and other information relating to the Common Interconnection Facilities that may be requested by any Party in connection with (A) the filing of such Party s tax returns, (B) the maintenance and retention of such Party s books and records, (C) any financial reporting or other disclosures that may be required, and (D) any audit, litigation or other proceeding by any Governmental Authority, including those that pertain to taxes; (iv) Collecting and providing any information, to the extent such information is in Operator s possession or is reasonably available to Operator, regarding the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area required for any reports to any Governmental Authorities; (v) Reporting promptly (and in any event within two (2) hours of becoming aware of an incident) any incident of explosion, fire, storm, or other emergency which could reasonably be expected to threaten life or property; (vi) Providing prompt written notice upon becoming aware of (A) any actual or potential violation of any applicable Law, including a requirement of any permit and (B) all events, occurrences, conditions, and issues that are material to, or are reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect on, the repair, management, operation and maintenance, or results of operations of the Common Interconnection Facilities, including notices of liens and claims of liens; and (vii) Providing such other reports and information as may be reasonably requested by either Party under the terms of this Agreement. (e) Warranties; Damage Remediation. Managing, supervising and verifying that all Persons providing warranties for the Common Interconnection Facilities comply promptly and diligently with all of their respective warranty obligations; providing such Persons timely notice of all matters affecting their respective warranty obligations; and coordinating and scheduling the provision of warranty work. (f) Environmental, Health and Safety Plan; Security Plan. (i) Implementing and prosecuting a written environmental, health and safety plan covering all operations with respect to the Common Interconnection Facilities; (ii) upon obtaining actual knowledge thereof, notifying the Parties of any of the following matters, to the extent related to the Common Interconnection Facilities or the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area, or the repair, management, operation and maintenance thereof: any inspection by Governmental Authorities; any pending administrative or judicial proceeding; any material release of hazardous materials; or any health, safety or security incidents; (iii) to the extent the Operator becomes aware of any environmental, health, safety or security matter with respect to the Common Interconnection Facilities that requires or is likely to require a corrective action, undertaking and completing such corrective action; and (iv) implementing and prosecuting the written security plan for the Common Interconnection Facilities and investigating all accidents or damage relating to the Common Interconnection Facilities or the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area, which security plan shall permit the Operator to temporarily restrict access by the Parties to the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area to the extent such restriction is reasonably determined by the Operator to be necessary for health, safety and operational reasons. (g) Compliance with Law; Permits. (i) Causing the Common Interconnection Facilities to comply with applicable Laws applicable to the repair, management, operation and maintenance of the Common Interconnection Facilities, including those relating to occupational safety and health or environmental protection, and taking such action as may be necessary to comply in a timely manner with any valid orders or requirements of any Governmental Authority affecting the Common Interconnection Facilities; provided, however, that Operator will provide the Parties with a reasonable period for response and discussion before any action is taken; and (ii) Causing the Common Interconnection Facilities to comply with applicable permits, including making payments required thereunder; provided, however, that the Operator shall be required to obtain only the permits required by applicable Law in connection with the performance of the Operator s duties under this Agreement. (h) Parts. Procuring all parts reasonably required from time to time, and receiving, unloading, handling, storing and maintaining all such parts in accordance with the manufacturers directions in such a manner as to comply with all warranty requirements. All parts procured and utilized by the Operator for performance under this Agreement during the term of any equipment warranties shall be of specification and quality required so as to in no way invalidate such warranties, or any portion thereof. (i) Security. Maintaining security of the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area consistent with Prudent Wind Industry Practices, which security may include temporarily restricting access by the Parties to the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area to the extent such restriction is reasonably determined by the Operator to be necessary for health, safety and operational reasons. C2. Emergencies. In the event of any emergency involving the Common Interconnection Facilities that is reasonably expected to result in possible personal injury or loss of life or damage to or destruction of property, the Operator shall take such action as may be reasonable and necessary, as determined by the Operator, to prevent, avoid or mitigate such injury, loss of life, damage or destruction and shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, report any such incident, including the Operator s response thereto, to the Parties. C3. O&M Budget. Within ninety (90) days after the Effective Date and no later than September 1 of each calendar year during the Term, the Operator shall deliver to the Parties a proposed budget for the repair, management, operation and maintenance of the Common Interconnection Facilities and the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area for the following calendar year, or the portions of the year remaining (each, an O&M Budget ). The Parties shall have thirty (30) days from receipt of a proposed O&M Budget either to approve same or to assist the Operator in preparing an approved O&M Budget by October 15th of each year. In the event that a proposed O&M Budget is not approved within the time indicated, the applicable O&M Budget for the previous year shall be utilized, until such time as the new proposed O&M Budget receives approval. C4. Restricted Actions. The Operator shall obtain approval of both Parties before engaging in activities with respect to the Common Interconnection Facilities that are neither (i) within the scope of the Services nor (ii) an emergency in nature before such permission is obtained. Operator may engage in activities with respect to the Common Interconnection Facilities required by applicable Law with prior notice to the Parties; provided, however, that unless action is imminently required, the Operator shall provide the Parties with a reasonable period for response and discussion before any action is taken. Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, the Operator shall not in any case undertake any of the following actions, without prior written consent of the Parties: (a) cause the creation or assumption by the Parties of any indebtedness for borrowed money or sell, assign, lease, pledge, mortgage, encumber, grant a security interest in, convey, or make any license, lien, exchange or other transfer or disposition of any property or assets of any Party or any component of the Common Interconnection Facilities or the Common Interconnection Facilities Easement Area; (b) make, enter into, execute, amend, terminate, modify or supplement any contract or agreement (including any labor or collective bargaining agreement) on behalf of or in the name of any Party; (c) settle, compromise, assign, pledge, transfer, release or consent to the compromise, assignment, pledge, transfer or release of, any claim, suit, debt, demand or judgment against or due by, any Party or related to a Project or submit any such claim or stipulate in respect thereof to a judgment, or consent to the same; (d) engage in any other transaction on behalf of a Party not expressly permitted under this Agreement; (e) perform or omit to perform any act which would cause any Person reasonably to believe that the Operator is a partner of a Party or authorized to bind such Party, except as expressly provided herein; or (f) expend, or commit to expend, O&M Costs in excess of the amount budgeted therefor in the O&M Budget with respect to any year without the prior written consent of the Parties; provided, that the Operator may, without the prior written consent of the Parties, spend up to One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000) in O&M Costs in a year to make or expedite repairs to the Common Interconnection Facilities as required due to an emergency as described in Section C2 above, so long as the Operator gives concurrent notice by facsimile, email or other written form to the Parties regarding the nature of the emergency and amount of the expenditure. EXHIBIT D TO COMMON FACILITIES AGREEMENT INSURANCE COVERAGES Type of Insurance Minimum Limits of Coverage
Commercial General Liability (CGL) $1,000,000 combined single limit per occurrence and in the aggregate, where applicable. If CGL insurance contains a general aggregate limit, it shall apply separately to the Shared Assets. Operator can choose to self-insure all of part of these required limits.
CGL insurance shall be written on an occurrence basis and shall cover liability arising from premises, operations, independent contractors, products/completed operations, property damage, personal injury and advertising injury, and liability assumed under an insured contract (including the tort liability of another assumed in a business contract), all with limits as specified above. Coverage shall include easement or license agreements in connection with construction or demolition operations on or within 50 feet of a railroad. There shall be no endorsement or modification of the CGL insurance limiting the scope of coverage for liability arising from explosion, collapse, or underground property damage. The CGL policy shall include coverage for sudden and accidental pollution exposure, or this coverage may be provided by a separate pollution policy.
Umbrella/Excess Liability $20,000,000 umbrella/excess liability combined single limit per occurrence and in the aggregate or AEGIS claims first-made basis. The commercial umbrella/excess insurance shall provide coverage in excess of the CGL insurance and the Business Automobile Liability insurance.
The CGL and commercial umbrella/excess insurance will provide that such insurance as afforded shall be primary as respects any claims, losses, damages, expenses, or liabilities arising out of this Agreement, and insured hereunder, and any insurance carried by the other Parties shall be excess of and noncontributing with insurance afforded by this policy, and shall provide for claims by one insured against another such that, except for the limits of insurance, the insurance shall apply separately to each insured against whom a claim is made or suit is brought.
All Risk Property All Risk Property Insurance, in an amount equal to full replacement cost or the probable maximum loss. The deductible, if any, may not exceed $250,000 each and every loss Coverage shall include waiver of subrogation against the Common Facilities Manager. All Risk Property Insurance shall include
(i) coverage for fire, flood and earthquake with sublimits equal to facilities with similar construction location and occupancy to the Shared Assets, with sublimits of no less than $10,000,000 each for flood and earthquake;
(ii) Boiler and Machinery Insurance covering all objects customarily subject to such insurance, including boilers and turbines as applicable; and
(iii) Business Interruption and Extra Expense Insurance, in an amount required to cover the Parties continuing and fixed expenses, resulting from interruption as a result of a physical damage loss, for a period of twelve (12) calendar months. The waiting period deductible may not exceed 60 days.
Business Interruption insurance shall cover partial delay of, or interruption in, the operation of the Shared Assets as a result of an insured peril covered under Property insurance as set forth above, to the extent available on commercially reasonable terms as determined by the Party, subject to a reasonable deductible. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, a Party shall not be required to have Business Interruption insurance until such Party s Phase begins commercial operation.

Broken Bow Wind, LLC Market-Based Rate Tariff
1. Availability. Seller makes electric energy and capacity available under this Tariff to any purchaser for resale. Seller also makes available to any purchaser the ancillary services listed in this Paragraph 1:
RTO/ISO Specific
PJM: Seller offers regulation and frequency response service, energy imbalance service, and operating reserve service (which includes spinning, 10-minute, and 30-minute reserves) for sale into the market administered by PJM Interconnection, L.L.C. (PJM) and, where the PJM Open Access Transmission Tariff permits, the self-supply of these services to purchasers for a bilateral sale that is used to satisfy the ancillary services requirements of the PJM Office of Interconnection.
New York: Seller offers regulation and frequency response service, and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute non-synchronous, 30-minute operating reserves, 10-minute spinning reserves, and 10-minute non-spinning reserves) for sale to purchasers in the market administered by the New York Independent System Operator, Inc.
New England: Seller offers regulation and frequency response service (automatic generator control), operating reserve service (which includes 10-minute spinning reserve, 10-minute non-spinning reserve, and 30-minute operating reserve service) to purchasers within the markets administered by the ISO New England, Inc.
California: Seller offers regulation service, spinning reserve service, and non-spinning reserve service to the California Independent System Operator Corporation (CAISO) and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to the CAISO.
MISO: Seller offers regulation service and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute spinning reserve and 10-minute supplemental reserve) for sale to the Midcontinent Independent System Operator, Inc. (MISO) and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to MISO.
Southwest Power Pool: Seller offers regulation service and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute spinning reserve and 10-minute supplemental reserve) for sale to the Southwest Power Pool, Inc. (SPP) and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to SPP.
Third Party Provider
Third-party ancillary services: Seller offers Regulation Service, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control Service, Energy and Generator Imbalance Service, Operating Reserve-Spinning, Operating Reserve-Supplemental, and Primary Frequency Response Service. Sales will not include the following: (1) sales to an RTO or an ISO, i.e., where that entity has no ability to self-supply ancillary services but instead depends on third parties; and (2) sales to a traditional, franchised public utility affiliated with the third-party supplier, or sales where the underlying transmission service is on the system of the public utility affiliated with the third-party supplier. Sales of Operating Reserve-Spinning and Operating Reserve-Supplemental will not include sales to a public utility that is purchasing ancillary services to satisfy its own open access transmission tariff requirements to offer ancillary services to its own customers, except where the Commission has granted authorization. Sales of Regulation Service and Reactive Supply and Voltage Control Service will not include sales to a public utility that is purchasing ancillary services to satisfy its own open access transmission tariff requirements to offer ancillary services to its own customers, except at rates not to exceed the buying public utility transmission provider s OATT rate for the same service or where the Commission has granted authorization.
2. Applicability: This Tariff is applicable to all sales of energy, capacity, and ancillary services by Seller, which are (a) subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission, and (b) not made pursuant to another tariff on file with the Commission.
3. Rates: All sales shall be made at rates established by agreement between the purchaser and Seller.
4. Other Terms and Conditions: All other terms and conditions shall be established by agreement between the purchaser and Seller.
5. Compliance with Commission Regulations: Seller shall comply with the provisions of 18 C.F.R. Part 35, Subpart H, as applicable, and with any conditions the Commission imposes in its orders concerning Seller s market-based rate authority, including orders in which the Commission authorizes Seller to engage in affiliate sales under this Tariff or otherwise restricts or limits the Seller s market-based rate authority. Failure to comply with the applicable provisions of 18 C.F.R. Part 35, Subpart H, and with any orders of the Commission concerning Seller s market-based rate authority, will constitute a violation of this Tariff.
6. Limitations and Exemptions Regarding Market-Based Rate Authority: The Commission granted Seller in Docket No. ER12-1238-000 the following waivers and blanket authorization: (i) waiver of Parts 41, 101 with the exception that waiver of the provisions of Part 101 that apply to hydropower licensees is not granted with respect to licensed hydropower projects, and 141 of the Commission s regulations except for 141.14 and 141.15; (ii) waiver of Subparts B and C of Part 35 of the Commission s regulations, except for Sections 35.12(a), 35.13(b), 35.15 and 35.16; and (iii) blanket approval as to Section 204 of the FPA and Part 34 of the Commission s regulations for all future issuances of securities and debt and assumptions of liabilities. The qualifying facility status of Seller s small power production facility has been certified and recertified in Docket No. QF12-66. 7. Seller Category. Seller is a Category 2 seller, as defined in 18 C.F.R. 35.36(a), in the Southwest Power Pool region, and a Category 1 seller in the Central, Northeast, Northwest, Southeast, and Southwest regions.
8. Effective Date. This Tariff is effective on such date as set by the Commission.
